title: Law
subtitle: Code as Law: From Rule of Man to Algorithmic Governance
introduction: Bitcoin is not just a technological innovation, but a legal experiment. It challenges the fundamental assumptions of traditional legal systems: Who has the right to make rules? How are contracts enforced? What are property rights? When code becomes the enforcer of rules, when cryptography replaces the coercive power of courts, we need to rethink the nature of law itself.

sections.title: Core Questions: Who Has the Right to Make Rules? How to Ensure Enforcement?

content.subtitle: Traditional Legal System
points: Legislative Power: Parliament or congress makes laws
Judicial Power: Courts interpret and adjudicate
Executive Power: Police and government departments enforce
Checks and Balances: Separation of powers, mutual supervision

content.subtitle: Code as Law
points: Automatic Execution: Certainty guarantee of protocol rules
Immutable: Rules are fixed after deployment
Transparent and Public: Everyone can view and verify
Trustless: Mathematical guarantees rather than human promises

sections.title: Contracts and Execution: From Paper to Code

content.subtitle: Traditional Contract Dilemmas
points: Execution Costs: Requires courts and enforcement systems
Time Delays: Lengthy litigation procedures
Geographic Limitations: Difficult cross-border enforcement
Interpretive Space: Textual ambiguity leads to disputes

content.subtitle: Innovation of Programmable Rules
points: Instant Execution: Conditions automatically trigger when met
Extremely Low Cost: No intermediaries or enforcement needed
Globally Effective: Not limited by jurisdictional boundaries
Certainty: Code logic is clear and unambiguous

sections.title: Property Rights Definition: Possession vs Control

content.subtitle: Traditional Property Rights System
points: Registration System: Government agencies confirm ownership
Legal Protection: Infringement can seek legal remedy
Transfer Procedures: Requires notarization and registration
State Endorsement: Relies on government credit

content.subtitle: Cryptographic Property Rights
points: Private Key as Ownership: Controlling private key means owning assets
Self-Sovereignty: No third-party confirmation needed
Instant Transfer: Signature completes the transfer
Anti-Counterfeiting: Cryptography guarantees uniqueness

content.subtitle: Traditional Dispute Resolution
points: Court Litigation: Time-consuming, laborious, and costly
Arbitration Mechanism: Relatively fast but still requires trust
Mediation and Negotiation: Depends on both parties' goodwill
Enforcement Guarantee: Requires coercive power support

content.subtitle: On-Chain Governance Mechanism
points: Preset Rules: Dispute situations pre-coded
Multi-Signature Mechanism: Multi-party joint decision-making
Time Locks: Providing period for reconsideration and appeal
Fork Choice: Community voting determines direction

content.subtitle: Regulatory Dilemmas
points: Jurisdictional Issues: Who governs decentralized systems
Enforcement Challenges: How to sanction anonymous participants
Technical Barriers: Regulatory understanding lags behind
Innovation vs Regulation: Balancing development and risks

content.subtitle: Compliance Exploration
points: KYC/AML: Identity verification and anti-money laundering
Regulatory Sandbox: Innovation pilot zones
Industry Self-Regulation: Establishing industry standards
Technical Regulation: Using technology to regulate technology

sections.title: Social Implications: Future Forms of Law

content.subtitle: Trend of Legal Codification
points: Rule Clarification: Reducing interpretive space
Execution Automation: Reducing enforcement costs
Transparency: Everyone can supervise
Globalization: Transcending jurisdictional boundaries

content.subtitle: New Balance Between Rule of Man and Rule of Law
points: Limitations of Code: Cannot handle all situations
Human Value: Moral judgment and flexibility
Hybrid Model: Code execution + human arbitration
Evolutionary Path: From forced to voluntary compliance

keyInsights: Execution is more important than formulation, automatic execution is superior to manual execution
The essence of property rights is control, technology can directly implement control
Transparent and predictable rules are more valuable than flexible but uncertain rules
The future of law may be a combination of human language and computer code

books.title: Law's Empire
books.author: Ronald Dworkin
books.description: Important work on legal interpretation theory

reflectionQuestions: If all protocols are executed by code, how would the role of law transform?
Are bugs in code equivalent to loopholes in law? Who should be responsible?
Would a completely transparent rule system lead to new forms of unfairness?
In a world where code is law, how do we protect vulnerable groups?
